irr-&-tmp-2026/literature-review/emergin.title: Emerging strategies in close proximity operations for space debris removal - A review
irr-&-tmp-2026/literature-review/emergin.description:
NOTE: This paper should be further read to understand the specific advantages and disadvantages of every method after further preliminary research. Active methods of space debris removal: Contactless lasers
ion beam shepherds
foam-based Contact Rigid (risk of generating fragments, easier to control) use of tentacles robotic arms de-orbiter modules
sling-sat methods Flexible (lesser risk of generating fragments, capable of capturing all shapes and sizes of debris, but harder to control nets) "there is a risk that fast tumbling targets can break or evade flexible systems"
tethers
harpoons
nets Passive methods of space debris removal: drag sails
solar sails
irr-&-tmp-2026/literature-review/emergin.sourcePath: IRR & TMP 2026/Literature Review/Emerging strategies in close proximity operations for space debris removal - A review.md

irr-&-tmp-2026/literature-review/space-d.title: Space debris remediation using space-based laser
irr-&-tmp-2026/literature-review/space-d.description:
Debris takes longer to de-orbit and decay due to lack of atmospheric drag
Entire orbital bands occupied by debris can be rendered inaccessible for satellites due to risk of collisions
Active removal methods (or rather, contact methods) such as de-orbiting modules are better suited for removing large, uncontrolled objects, not small fragments due to cost efficiency and difficulty of control.
Ground-based strategies ()
irr-&-tmp-2026/literature-review/space-d.sourcePath: IRR & TMP 2026/Literature Review/Space debris remediation using space-based laser.md

irr-&-tmp-2026/context-or-urgency-quotes.title: Context or Urgency Quotes
irr-&-tmp-2026/context-or-urgency-quotes.description:
"Space debris is a growing concern, as most recently demonstrated on 2 October 2022 when ESA’s CryoSat had to actively dodge a 3 cm shard from an Agena-D rocket upper stage. Of the tens of thousands of such tracked space objects in orbit, only 4,000 or so are operational satellites." Time to clean up low Earth orbit
"In addition to being launch risks, satellites making active manoeuvres to avoid crashes use up extra fuel, thereby shortening their lifespan and hastening their member- ship to the space junk graveyard." Time to clean up low Earth orbit
"Donald Kessler proposed a cascade effect, now named after him, for when the space pollu- tion density is such that each collision pro- duces new objects that lead to more collisions. Unfortunately, he concluded that the space environment was already unstable in 2009." Time to clean up low Earth orbit
"Space debris is a growing concern for astronauts and satellites as companies launch more missions into space, including mega-constellations such as the SpaceX’s Starlink project, which now numbers more than 1.400 satellites already in orbit" ET-Class - An Energy Transfer-Based Classification of Space Debris Removal Methods and Missions
"It is estimated by the European Space Agency (ESA) that 130 million objects smaller than 1 cm, 900.000 objects between 1 and 10 cm, and 34.000 objects greater than 10 cm are orbiting Earth up to the enormous speeds of 28.100 km/h." ET-Class - An Energy Transfer-Based Classification of Space Debris Removal Methods and Missions
"Since the start of the space era, more than 5000 launches have been carried out, each carrying satellites for many disparate uses, such as Earth observation or communication" Active Space Debris Removal System
"According to NASA, more than 11,000 metric tons of space debris is present in Earth’s orbit" Emerging strategies in close proximity operations for space debris removal - A review
"Defunct spacecraft or other non-functional man-made objects have accumulated, and as a result, are prone to collide with other objects, which can cause more debris and could hypothetically result in a chain process known as the Kessler syndrome" Emerging strategies in close proximity operations for space debris removal - A review
"Altogether, a mass of over 8,000 tons of debris is currently orbiting the planet, posing as a threat for operative satellites." RemoveDEBRIS - An in-orbit demonstration of technologies for the removal of space debris
"However, selecting which technologies merit priority investment and development remains challenging, not least because prioritizing which debris is most important to remove." Active Debris Removal - It’s Complicated

irr-&-tmp-2026/strategies.html.title: Strategies
irr-&-tmp-2026/strategies.html.description:
ACTIVE DEBRIS REMOVAL (ADR)"The process to rendezvous with a piece of space junk and remove it from orbit is called active debris removal" https://www.esa.int/Space_Safety/Space_Debris/Active_debris_removalActive Debris Removal - It’s ComplicatedNOTE: This paper should be further read to understand the specific advantages and disadvantages of every method after further preliminary research. Active methods of space debris removal: Contactless lasers ion beam shepherds foam-based Contact Rigid (risk of generating fragments, easier to control) use of tentacles robotic arms de-orbiter modules sling-sat methods Flexible (lesser risk of generating fragments, capable of capturing all shapes and sizes of debris, but harder to control nets) "there is a risk that fast tumbling targets can break or evade flexible systems" tethers harpoons nets Passive methods of space debris removal: drag sails solar sails Emerging strategies in close proximity operations for space debris removal - A reviewSPACE DEBRIS REMOVAL STRATEGIESNOTE: This paper should be further read to understand the specific advantages and disadvantages of every method after further preliminary research.
ET-Class - An Energy Transfer-Based Classification of Space Debris Removal Methods and MissionsTime to clean up low Earth orbitCONTEXTNAME: RemoveDEBRIS - Net capture CAPTURE METHOD: Net YEAR: 2018 CLIENT STATUS: Non-cooperative ANGULAR MOMENTUM: Tumbling REUSABILITY: High TIME EFFECTIVENESS: 7/10 SCALABILITY: PossibleNAME: RemoveDEBRIS - Harpoon CAPTURE METHOD: Harpoon YEAR: 2018 CLIENT STATUS: Non-cooperative ANGULAR MOMENTUM: None REUSABILITY: Medium TIME EFFECTIVENESS: 7/10 SCALABILITY: PossibleRemoveDEBRIS - An in-orbit demonstration of technologies for the removal of space debrisAssessment of Active Space Debris Removal Methods Using the Weighted Sum Model (WSM) FLEXIBILITY LIGHTWEIGHT MULTI-ORBIT NAME: RemoveDEBRIS - Dragsail CAPTURE METHOD: Drag sail YEAR: 2018 CLIENT STATUS: N/A ANGULAR MOMENTUM: N/A REUSABILITY: Low TIME EFFECTIVENESS: 5/10 SCALABILITY: Low
Assessment of active methods for removal of LEO debrisAstroscale's space debris removal demo mission funded for 2026 launchNAME: ELSA-D CAPTURE METHOD: Magnetic YEAR: 2021 CLIENT STATUS: Cooperative ANGULAR MOMENTUM: Tumbling REUSABILITY: High TIME EFFECTIVENESS: SCALABILITY: HighActive Space Debris Removal SystemNAME: Foam-based Capture CAPTURE METHOD: Foam drag YEAR: 2017 CLIENT STATUS: Cooperative ANGULAR MOMENTUM: None REUSABILITY: Low TIME EFFECTIVENESS: SCALABILITY: Low COMMERCIAL NAME: SARAH CAPTURE METHOD: Robotic-arm YEAR: 2025 CLIENT STATUS: Non-cooperative ANGULAR MOMENTUM: Tumbling REUSABILITY: High TIME EFFECTIVENESS: 9/10 SCALABILITY: UnsureActive Debris Removal (ADR) - A Remedial Strategy for Sustainable Satellite Operations

info_showCustomIcons.description: Show custom icons for files and folders

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_minCollapseDepth.description: Only allow outline items to be collapsed if they are at least this many levels deep in the tree.

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
